review: I found Clare, the former hero and rogue loosely based on Westley, somewhat charming. His humorous commentary and engaging banter with Beatrice offered a pleasant counterpoint to her sharp retorts. However, his character alone wasn’t enough to redeem the book for me.

The story carried a pervasive sadness, with the surviving heroes and heroines failing to feel triumphant after the loss of their fearless leader. As the ten-year reunion of their victory approached, they were forced to confront their queen. Despite being a book that promised fun, none of us found any enjoyment in it.

The anachronisms were frustrating. While I appreciate the use of magic to enhance a medieval-like setting, I couldn't accept magic tapestries functioning as texting devices. The ubiquitous Starbucks-like brew shops, shadow play dramas beamed into homes, and ride-sharing services for carriages felt too modern for my taste. I prefer my cozy fantasy without contemporary inventions and conveniences, even when explained by magic.

Despite my initial excitement, I struggled to connect with this story. I managed to read only about 30% before setting it aside, and I never felt motivated to return. Instead, I found comfort in re-reading some of my favorites, as each subsequent book failed to engage me as well. While I wish I could attribute this solely to my own preferences, I suspect I'm not alone in my lack of enthusiasm for this one.

I was thrilled to read this book, as *The Princess Bride* is one of my top five favorite movies. My library even has a dedicated shelf for it, complete with memorabilia like a board game, bobbleheads, Funkos, and wine bottles from a special screening at Alamo Drafthouse. Upon discovering the comparisons to this book, I knew I had to dive in.
conclusion: Despite my high expectations and initial excitement, this book failed to engage me. The pervasive sadness, jarring anachronisms, and lack of narrative cohesion overshadowed the few charming moments, leaving me disappointed.

review: The ending was both satisfying and unexpected; I only saw it coming just moments before it unfolded. It wove the narrative together beautifully. As they are reluctantly reunited, they must confront their shared past, resolve lingering differences, and learn to work together once more for a new quest. The story is propelled by past misunderstandings, generating significant drama, and at times, I found myself wanting to shake some characters out of their self-pity. However, once honest communication emerges among them, the narrative gains much-needed momentum.

The characters confront their past struggles and emerge stronger as a result. Vandra, a newcomer to the group of original friends, consistently shines and adds to the story's enjoyment. I especially appreciated the emotional depth and growth displayed by the characters throughout the narrative.

While the setting offers a humorous backdrop, the story itself delves into deeper, more dramatic themes.
conclusion: Overall, This Will Be Fun is a whimsical fantasy with heavy emotional depth. It combines humor and drama effectively, offering a compelling story of friendship, reconciliation, and personal growth.

It centers on the reluctant reunion of the remaining heroes for the queen's wedding. While I appreciated the character-driven adventure, the prolonged miscommunication and avoidance of issues were occasionally frustrating. The stakes felt low, but I enjoyed the meandering atmosphere of the potentially world-ending quests.

The characters are deeply flawed yet relatable, each embodying vulnerabilities that resonate with our humanity. Clare grapples with imposter syndrome, Elowen fears love, and Beatrice wrestles with survivor's guilt. I enjoyed their witty banter and tender moments, along with their growth throughout the story. However, their decade-long avoidance of issues resulted in frustrating miscommunications.

The writing is engaging, highlighting clever banter and relationship development. The dialogue and emotional moments are well-crafted, though the pacing of the communication issues could use some improvement.

The story unfolds in a captivating mixed modern/medieval fantasy world infused with magic. While I enjoyed the setting and magical elements, I felt that the world-building was somewhat underdeveloped, which affected my overall score in comparison to other aspects.

This book explores themes of survivor's guilt, fear of love, and imposter syndrome, while addressing several heavy topics. Content warnings include violence, death, war, manipulation, detailed injuries, sexual content, isolation, alcohol use, as well as mentions of kidnapping, sibling loss, and infidelity.

This story avoids the typical hero's journey and romantic fantasy tropes, delivering instead a character-driven adventure rich in banter and relationship development. It evokes the charm of *Galavant* and *The Princess Bride*. While romance plays a significant role, it remains a subplot rather than the main focus.
conclusion: Overall, I loved this book for its flawed yet relatable characters, engaging banter, and unique take on a post-heroic world. While the miscommunication and avoidance of problems were frustrating, the emotional payoff in the harder conversations was worth it. The world and magic were captivating, and the meandering tone of the story added to its charm.

However, I found the twist predictable, as I guessed it early on, which diminished the story's climax. Ten years later, after one hero's death, the remaining three reunite for the former Princess's wedding and are unexpectedly drawn into another epic adventure. While the premise is intriguing, the execution ultimately fell short.

The story unfolds through three POV chapters, each centering on one of the remaining heroes. Unfortunately, only one character was likable, which hindered my investment in their journeys. By the 85% mark, I found myself eager for the book to conclude, as I was indifferent to the outcome.

This book fits comfortably within the cozy fantasy genre and introduces sapphic elements that add a unique touch. However, despite these appealing aspects, it ultimately falls short of being particularly memorable.
conclusion: While *This Will Be Fun* offers a cozy fantasy with an engaging premise and sapphic elements, its predictable twist, unlikable characters, and my personal bias toward one of the authors made it a mediocre read for me. It’s a decent choice for fans of the genre but lacks the depth and originality to make it memorable.

review: The villains, especially Todrick van Thorn, lack sufficient development. Certain plot conveniences challenge believability, and the late introduction of a time-travel element raises questions about its earlier omission. Set in the enchanting realm of Mythria, the story follows four estranged heroes summoned to Queen Thessia's wedding. What starts as an awkward reunion quickly evolves into a thrilling adventure as dark forces emerge, jeopardizing both the realm and the heroes' opportunities to heal past wounds and reignite lost romances.

The novel excels in character development, presenting protagonists with authentic and relatable emotional scars. Beatrice grapples with guilt over Galwell's death, Elowen battles self-imposed isolation, and Clare struggles with his heroic persona, weaving a rich tapestry of internal conflicts.

The collaborative writing is cohesive and maintains a consistent voice throughout. The narrative skillfully alternates between four perspectives, providing unique insights. While the pacing falters at times in the middle sections, the final act culminates in a satisfying crescendo of action and emotional resolution.

Mythria is vividly depicted, yet certain elements feel underdeveloped. The magic system is captivating, but the realm's politics and history could benefit from deeper exploration. Standout locations like the cozy Needle pub, the opulent Vermillion Vale, crystal caves, and the atmospheric Night Dragon inn enrich the narrative.

The authors skillfully incorporate inventive elements like the Clare Convention and its impersonators, Magical Truth or Dare, and the catchy celebrity couple name "Claretrice." They seamlessly blend modern fantasy tropes with traditional quest themes, enhancing the story's richness.
conclusion: *This Will Be Fun* delivers on its promise of adventure, romance, and emotional depth. Despite some world-building gaps and plot conveniences, the strong character work, engaging romance arcs, and ultimately satisfying conclusion make it a worthy addition to any romantasy lover's library.

review: The plot is overly simplistic, featuring heroes who are repeatedly captured by one-dimensional villains and saved either by luck or the non-POV character, Vandra. The antagonists are stereotypical and prone to lengthy monologues, while the heroes' strategy to save the kingdom is disappointingly basic. Additionally, the story is marred by abrupt emotional confessions and a twist that significantly undermines any character development.

The main characters—Beatrice, Elowen, and Clare—are the last surviving members of The Four heroes who saved the kingdom a decade ago. While the aftermath of their Happily Ever After holds promise for exploration, the characters often feel self-absorbed and inept. They spend much of their time indulging in self-pity, pursuing romantic interests, and bickering, which ultimately renders them more frustrating than endearing.

The revelation that the author consists of three individuals reminded me of movie productions that enlist script doctors to salvage struggling projects. This collaboration felt disjointed, contributing to the book's overall messiness and positioning it as a strong contender for my Most Disappointing Read of 2024.

The story unfolds in a typical Ye Olde Fantasy Worlde, adorned with princesses, castles, and heroic quests. Yet, the introduction of anachronisms—such as magical Uber, Starbucks, and TV shows called "shadow plays"—feels forced, detracting from the overall world-building. The satire of contemporary culture comes across as heavy-handed and ultimately ineffective.
The humor falls flat, lacking effectiveness as both comedy and satire. The attempts at wit and cultural commentary feel awkward and excessive.

The book is promoted as a mix of *The Princess Bride* and *People We Meet on Vacation*, but it resembles the slapstick comedy of *Robin Hood: Men in Tights*, albeit with less humor. While it aims for satire, the execution lacks subtlety, leaving the humor feeling flat.
conclusion: *This Will Be Fun* falls short in nearly every aspect—comedy, fantasy, and romance. Despite a few redeeming moments, such as Vandra’s character and Clare’s amusing entrepreneurial antics, the book is a disappointing read. Even without the context of the US election, my feelings about the book would remain unchanged.

  The humor fell flat. The attempts at being funny or clever, such as the heroine crocheting a phrase onto a pillow (despite crochet not being historically accurate), felt forced and didn’t land. The overall tone was frothy and silly, but not in a way that I found enjoyable.

  The plot felt disjointed and unengaging. The introduction of a divorce in the first chapter and the unlikely pairing of a lesbian with a lady assassin in the second chapter didn’t draw me in. The pacing and structure failed to hold my interest.

The three POV characters—Beatrice, Elowen, and Clare—are compellingly developed, each facing their own struggles: Elowen's isolation, Beatrice's guilt and trauma, and Clare's battle with Imposter Syndrome, despite his fame. Their personal journeys are central to the narrative. The novel primarily revolves around two couples: Clare and Beatrice (a heterosexual pairing) and Elowen and Vandra (a Sapphic pairing). Both couples embody the second-chance romance and rivals-to-lovers tropes, making it easy to root for them throughout the story.

The world-building is enchanting, featuring imaginative medieval fantasy adaptations of modern concepts, like a horse-and-buggy alternative to Uber and a fan convention backdrop. These details infuse the story with a distinct and humorous charm.
The novel is delightful and engaging, frequently prompting laughter. Its playful tone is expertly balanced with a deeper exploration of overcoming trauma, making it both entertaining and meaningful.
conclusion: *This Will Be Fun* is a delightful blend of humor, romance, and character-driven storytelling. It balances playful elements with deeper themes of trauma and healing, making it both entertaining and emotionally resonant. The relationships—both romantic and platonic—are the heart of the story, and the world-building adds a unique charm. I highly recommend it and hope for a sequel!

review: The story centers on retired heroes long after they've saved their realm, yet it leans more towards romance than fantasy. The fantasy elements feel secondary, as modern concepts are clumsily substituted with their fantasy counterparts. While this approach might resonate with some readers, it fell short of my expectations for a fantasy-driven narrative.

The main characters are relatable, yet they lack a deep connection to the fantasy world. One engages in cosplay as a beloved TV character and interacts with fans on an anonymous chat board, while another navigates the challenges of a messy divorce. These traits anchor them in modernity rather than in the realm of traditional fantasy heroes.

While the book is marketed as a "Narnia for adults," its fantasy elements often feel superficial. Unlike the profound depth and heart found in the works of C.S. Lewis or T. Kingfisher, this story resembles a contemporary romance with only a thin layer of fantasy.
conclusion: While the book has an intriguing premise and relatable characters, it falls short of delivering a compelling fantasy experience. It feels more like a contemporary romance with a fantasy backdrop, which may not resonate with readers seeking a deeper, more immersive fantasy story.

The book effectively deconstructs the Chosen One trope and explores the fate of beloved heroes within a unique medieval-meets-modern Shrek-style world. Its humor and subversion of traditional heroism make for a refreshing read.

The main characters—Beatrice, Clare, Elowen, and Galwell—are vividly flawed and morally ambiguous, portrayed with both humor and empathy. Beatrice grapples with a recent divorce and struggles with alcohol, while Clare captivates as a charming influencer. Elowen remains isolated in her treetop home, and Vandra, a former assassin, introduces an intriguing dynamic. The characters' tangled lives and interactions are the standout elements of the story.

The book exudes a light, goofy charm that invites readers to engage with it on its own terms. Its humorous worldbuilding effortlessly blends medieval and modern elements, creating a unique and entertaining experience that doesn’t take itself too seriously.

This adult novel offers a cozy, light fantasy atmosphere. It's neither dark nor brooding, and it lacks intense drama or romance, making it less appealing to readers seeking those elements. Instead, it is ideal for those looking for a breezy, enjoyable read.
conclusion: *This Will Be Fun* is a light, humorous, and character-driven novel that deconstructs the Chosen One trope with a quirky, medieval-meets-modern world. While the plot lacks stakes and the title is off-putting, the tone, characters, and worldbuilding make it an enjoyable, cozy read for those seeking something fun and breezy.
